prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in two galaxies at z=5.8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] and FIR continuum in one galaxy at z=5.786, and one galaxy at 5.828. We can place them in the centers of adjacent basebands in one sideband, so we observe them together to save on overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As we have two galaxies very close in redshift, we can use a single correlator setup to observe [CII] in both galaxies. This is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for two individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive. We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the lower sideband to 278.3 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (34 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the galaxy at z=5.828 (we note that in the OT we set the redshift of each galaxy to be z=5.828; when we did not do this, it tried to change the central frequency for each object, which is not wanted). We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. We center the second baseband in the lower sideband at 280.1 GHz, which will cover [CII] from the galaxy at z=5.786. Finally, we set the two basebands in the upper sideband at 290.2 and 292.1 GHz, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution (34 km/s at these frequencies), as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected FWHM for [CII].
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission in each object) is 0.08 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which, when combined with our other science goals, will be sufficient to obtain a detection of the dust emission in a stack of our full sample.
The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 5 min per object, for a total of 0.5 hr including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to ensure we observe [CII] even if is spatially offset from the UV continuum.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in two galaxies, at z=5.786 and 5.828. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for these galaxies, which, as shown in Table 1, are 7.5 and 3.9 mJy. As these objects lie very close in redshift, we elected to place them in the same science goal, using the same correlator set-up, as we save significantly on calibration overheads. As we wish to detect this line in 3-4 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at 4-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We thus choose an rms flux density of 0.98 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in four z=5.9-6.0 galaxies
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] and FIR continuum in four galaxies at z=5.93-5.98. We can observe four galaxies in a single tuning, so we place them together to save time on calibration overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As we have four galaxies very close in redshift, we can use a single correlator setup to observe [CII] in all four galaxies. This is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for four individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive, even when accounting for the reduced integration time for some objects. We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 273.96 Ghz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (34 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the three galaxies at z=5.929, 5.940 and 5.942 (we note that in the OT we set the redshift of each galaxy to be z=5.929; when we did not do this, it tried to change the central frequency for each object, which is not wanted). We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. In fact, given the width of the baseband, no line will be closer than 700 km/s from the edge of the band, even after accounding for a likely 200 km/s difference between the systemic redshift and the Lyman alpha redshift (the known redshifts come from Lyman alpha, which is systematically emitted redward of systemic due to kinematical and resonant scattering effects; Song et al. 2014). We center the second baseband in the upper sideband at 272.06 GHz, which will cover [CII] from the galaxy at z=5.979. Finally, we set the two basebands in the lower sideband at 258.96 and 257.06 GHz, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution (33 km/s at these frequencies), as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected FWHM for [CII].
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission in each object) is 0.03 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which, when combined with our other science goals, will be sufficient to obtain a detection of the dust emission in a stack of our full sample.
The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 28 min per object, for a total of 3.3 hr including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to ensure we observe [CII] even if is spatially offset from the UV continuum.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in four galaxies, at z=5.929, 5.940, 5.942 and 5.979. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for these galaxies, which, as shown in Table 1, are 1.86, 6.11, 2.71 and 1.49 mJy. As these objects lie very close in redshift, we elected to place them in the same science goal, using the same correlator set-up, as we save significantly on calibration overheads. As we wish to detect this line in 3-4 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at 4-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We thus choose an rms flux density of 0.373 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in one galaxy at z=6.08
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] and FIR continuum in one galaxy at z=6.08.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 268.4 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (35 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for this galaxy. We center the remaining three basebands at lower frequencies, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution (34 km/s at these frequencies), as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected [CII] FWHM.
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission) is 0.02 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which, when combined with our other science goals, will be sufficient to obtain a detection of the dust emission in a stack of our full sample.
The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 40 min, for a total of 1.15 hr including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to ensure we observe [CII] even if is spatially offset from the UV continuum.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in one galaxy at z=6.08. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for this galaxy, which, as shown in Table 1, is 1.07 mJy. As we wish to detect this line in 3-4 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at 4-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We thus choose an rms flux density of 0.27 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in one galaxy at z=7.55
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CII] and FIR continuum in one galaxy at z=7.55

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the lower sideband to 222.3 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (42 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for this galaxy. We center the remaining three basebands at higher frequencies, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected [CII] FWHM.
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission) is 0.03 mJy at ~160um rest-frame, which, when combined with our other science goals, will be sufficient to obtain a detection of the dust emission in a stack of our full sample.
The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 21 min, for a total of 44 min including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to ensure we observe [CII] even if is spatially offset from the UV continuum.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in one galaxy at z=7.55. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for this galaxy, which, as shown in Table 1, is 1.84 mJy. As we wish to detect this line in 3-4 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at 5-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We thus choose an rms flux density of 0.368 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a survey of [CII] 158 micron emission from eight normal star-forming galaxies with spectroscopically confirmed redshifts of z=5.8 to 7.6. This emission line provides a unique tracer of the dynamical mass in these galaxies, which can constrain the total amount of gas present. We will use these observations to answer the question of whether an increase in the typical gas mass fractions with increasing redshift is the dominant physical cause behind an observed increase in the stellar-mass to halo-mass ratio at z > 5. These observations will also have tremendous legacy value, as they will probe the evolution of the ratio between [CII] and far-infrared luminosity to the highest redshifts. Finally, by observing the luminosity of this line at such high redshifts, we will pave the way for the future use of ALMA as a redshift machine, as [CII] represents the best chance for spectroscopic redshifts in the epoch of reionization, where Lyman alpha has become diffifult to observe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
